content.description: This is a fun little number that has a few spooky moves getting to the 2nd bolt.  After the second clip, the climbing eases as the angle decreases.
content.location: Fourth route to the right of the mine.

climbs.name: Rapid Fire
climbs.fa: Derek Peavey, bolted by Tim Wilhelmi

content.description:
This goes straight up the face left of

Monstrosity

.  Continuous crimps without much of a rest eventually lead to a good jug around the 6th bolt or so.  From here, you traverse up and left to the anchors, with a few more hard moves.  From my understanding, holds on

Monstrosity

are on as long as you don't traverse over for a no hands rest.
content.location: This is the second climb to the left on the Mineshaft Wall.

content.description: Looks can be deceiving on this route. Fun moves and solid holds prove surprising. Crux comes when working over the obvious bulge. Not a bad route but seems to get little action.
content.protection: 5 bolts? and two open cold shuts.
content.location:
This is the first route as you round the corner from

It Is What It Is

. Just right of

Death and Disfiguration

.

climbs.name: Monstrosity
climbs.fa: T. Wilhelmi, J. Bowes, C. Wilhelmi

content.description: This is probably the best 5.10 at The Palace.  Follow a line a good holds through multiple roofs.  No one move will throw you, but the pump might.  This is a great line to run laps on, if no one is waiting in line.
content.location: This is the second route to the right of the mine shaft.

content.description: Scramble up until you get the to the overhanging section and the fun begins. Stick the 3 or so moves (the holds are solid) and tag the mantle. FUN, but like summer vacation when you're 10, over too quickly. More like a V2+ boulder problem.
content.location: It's the second climb as you enter the Palace, just down the trail from Drawbridge. Climbs the prow at the beginning of Mineshaft Wall.

content.description: Clip the first bolt from a good stance, figure out a slightly awkward sequence to gain a big ledge, and then scurry up the left side of the prow utilizing good holds on and near the left arete.
content.protection:
3 bolts, to 2 open cold shuts.

Per Felix Wong, this route has 4 bolts.
content.location: This route climbs the first pillar encountered on the right while walking up the Cedar Creek trail.

climbs.name: Death and Disfiguration
climbs.fa: D. Peavey, T. Wilhelmi, S. Shannon '04

content.description:
This route is worth the effort, but the start is a little awkward and insecure.  If you mess up in the first 10-15ft, you could touch down if your belayer is not paying attention.

Follow a left angling crack system to a few powerful moves over a roof.  Angle up to the right on a few steep moves to the anchors.
content.location: This is the sixth route to the right of the mine.

content.description: Scamper up the really slopey, chossy, and root-filled top of the mineshaft entrance without knocking out your belayer with a large rock (crux). Continue with crimpy climbing with a couple of good shake-outs to a long reach just before the chains. I've watched many heart-breaking falls at this final move.
content.protection: 5 bolts and a two bolt anchor. You may want to pre-clip the first bolt.
content.location:
Begin left of

Rapid Fire

starting on the ledge above the mineshaft entrance.

content.description: This climb starts out with thin 5.10 face climbing up to a left ward traverse to an obvious under-clinging hold.  The guidebook says to go big with a lunge to a jug, but there are 2 other ways to climb the route.  If you are tall, you can get a shoulder wrenching high gaston out right and do the move static.  It is also possible to bypass the move on the right with 5.11a face climbing.  Unique moves....
content.location: This is the 3rd route to the right of the mine.
